name: NewYorker
text: President Trump has continually misrepresented what is happening in the country as an outbreak of anarchy that he is heroically cleaning up. https://t.co/RslDcyWRGl

name: NewYorker
text:
The economist Richard Koo explains why the U.S. economy's recovery  may be a long and painful one.
https://t.co/0vCVE4Z1ID

name: NewYorker
text:
Bob Dylan's "Rough and Rowdy Ways," his first album of original songs since 2012, feels unusually attuned to its moment.
https://t.co/2TIs97oSPD

name: NewYorker
text: “The main thing is do unto others as you would have them do unto you,” the saxophonist Sonny Rollins says. “Sure, everybody knows it, but nobody lives by it.” https://t.co/wHZtBTirTJ

name: NewYorker
text: Venezuela’s regime is using the coronavirus pandemic to strengthen its hold on power: more than a dozen health-care workers and journalists have been detained for speaking publicly about missing supplies or questioning the official infection count. https://t.co/eRfrEAXHU5

name: NewYorker
text:
In his latest Kvetchbook, Barry Blitt illustrates some responses to the Supreme Court’s landmark L.G.B.T.Q. ruling.

https://t.co/DD6vlsQLtZ

name: NewYorker
text: “If you ask me how we beat Ebola in West Africa, there’s a three-second answer: contact tracing": how public-health experts in Massachusetts are applying lessons from Ebola to the COVID-19 outbreak in the United States. https://t.co/KJpb4LJuc0

name: NewYorker
text: In “See You Next Time,” a glimpse of the dynamics of the ritual nail-salon visit, “fabulous, fantastic, blinged out, exciting, happy, and bright” is how one patron describes the feeling her new set of acrylics gives her. https://t.co/4iWlIlY7Q4

name: NewYorker
text: "An officer turned to me and said, ‘Can the women move to the back? We don’t want to hurt them.’ I said, ‘Bro, are you lost? The front lines *are* black women." A social worker in Atlanta discusses a weekend of unrest in the city. https://t.co/Q2cS4PUoLg

name: NewYorker
text: In the years after her mother and eight other members of the Emanuel A.M.E. Church were murdered by a white supremacist, Reverend Sharon Risher rose above her doubts in humanity to become an activist against gun violence. https://t.co/FJelvgWFCd

name: NewYorker
text: “The possibility of God considering Harvey’s fate ﬂoated across his mind”: New fiction by Emma Cline. https://t.co/3IujDQ3UUn

name: NewYorker
text: Jill Lepore explores the historical precedent for rebuilding American democracy. “Nothing so sharpens one’s appreciation for democracy as bearing witness to its demolition,” she writes. https://t.co/UDsWjoevwI

name: NewYorker
text:
RT @mannocchia: And, all of a sudden, it all made sense. It wasn’t me. My city is hurting. My city is depressed. My city is on fire.

A great piece by Luke Mogelson on the Southside of Minneapolis.
@NewYorker 

https://t.co/xUWB4YDHDJ

name: NewYorker
text: In the '60s, the Black Panther Party arose to confront police brutality, and the Panthers created a visual archive of justified outrage. We still haven’t fully seen the art made by those 20th-century black artists. https://t.co/c2EHbvAFYj

name: NewYorker
text: Phoebe Bridgers on listening to Elliott Smith, reading Joan Didion, and her new album, which contains “lots of California and lots of fucking ghosts.” https://t.co/MfCzDxKa9I
